intro: Calamus erectus var. macrocarpus, commonly known as the giant sedge, is a tall, herbaceous plant native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae and is characterized by its tall, slender stems and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are typically green or brown in color. It thrives in wetland environments and is often found in marshes and along riverbanks. Due to its unique morphology and ecological role, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
